Graphical abstract A one-step procedure to exhaustively reduce aromatic esters and carboxylic acids to their corresponding tolyl derivatives is a significant transformation in organic synthesis, which remains challenging in homogeneous catalysis. In this study, it’s achieved by using the well-defined phosphinesulfonate chelated cobalt-based catalyst (Co(dppbsa)), along with NaBArF 4 as the basic additive and (MeO)2MeSiH as the reductant. Particularly, this cobalt catalysis proceeds through ether intermediates. Experimental combined theoretical results support it follows an outer-sphere ionic hydrosilylation mechanism and the in situ formed cationic siloxane species are involved in the rate-limiting hydride transfer. The same system also enables the catalytic deoxygenation of aliphatic esters, aliphatic acids, and amides but terminating at the corresponding ethers, alkanols and secondary amines, respectively. These findings open up novel avenues for the catalytic application of phosphinesulfonate chelated complexes, potentially serving as the foundation for the exhaustive reduction of carboxylic skeletons with cobalt. Keywords Cobalt catalysis Homogeneous Exhaustive reduction Aromatic esters Carboxylic acids Data availability I have shared my data as the supporting information. 1 Introduction The reduction of carboxylic compounds, such as esters, carboxylic acids, and amides, play privileged role in the interconversion of structural motifs [1]. This is generally approached by the action of in-situ formed or extra added metal hydride agents, enabling formation of the corresponding alkanols [2]. Meanwhile, the deoxygenative formation of ethers and amines from ester and amide feedstocks represents as an alternative protocol [3]. By contrast, the deoxygenative reduction to the methyl oxidation state, denoted as exhaustive reduction, remains underexplored. Traditionally, such a transformation is achieved by a multi-step sequence via initial reduction to the alkanol, structural motif interconversion to the alkyl halide, and consequent reduction to the methyl product (Scheme 1 A) [4]. Therein, the direct alkanol-to-methyl conversion can also be reached by the advanced catalytic hydrogenolysis [5]. In this domain, various heterogeneous catalysts have been developed for the reductive transformation of esters to hydrocarbons [6]. However, most of these catalytic systems proceed under harsh conditions (typically > 200 °C) and mainly deliver decarboxylation products. By comparison, the homogenously catalyzed exhaustive reduction of carboxylic esters receives much less attention. The pioneer studies by Yamamoto’s group reported electron-deficient B(C6F5)3-catalyzed exhaustive reduction of aliphatic esters and carboxylic acids with triethylsilane (Et3SiH, Scheme 1B) [7]. Unfortunately, the aromatic counterparts largely terminate at the alkanol stage under the same protocol. Later, Newman’s group documented the successful exhaustive reduction of aromatic esters catalyzed by the combination of Ni(cod)2 and 1,3-dicyclohexylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate salt (ICy·HBF4) in the presence of 1,1,3,3-tetramethyldisiloxane (TMDSO, Scheme 1B) [8]. Wu’s group, using ammonia borane (NH3·BH3) as the reductant, reported the first titanium-catalyzed exhaustive reduction of both aromatic esters and aromatic carboxylic acids to their corresponding tolyl compounds (Scheme 1B) [9]. Very recently, Mejía’s group reported the use of boronic acid catalysts for the reduction of esters and carboxylic acids to a methyl group in the presence of ammonia borane as a hydrogen donor (Scheme 1B) [10]. Noteworthily, homogenous catalysis involving carboxylic acids are more challenging due to deactivation of the catalysts via over-coordination of the catalytic center by carboxylate ligand or destroying the active metal–hydride species by –COOH [11]. For instance, the nickel-catalysis is not active to carboxylic acids at all, while the B(C6F5)3-catalyzed exhaustive reduction of aliphatic acids requires much excessive Et3SiH and only a moderate-to-good yield of the tolyl products (34∼87%) was obtained under the titanium-catalysis [7–9]. Cobalt complexes show enormous potential in catalytic reduction of carbonyl and carboxylic compounds, benefiting by a versatile while structurally tunable ligand system. Several molecularly defined homogeneous cobalt catalysts or cobalt catalytic systems have been developed by the group of Milstein, [12] Jones, [13] Gunanathan, [14] de Bruin, [11] and Mandal, [15] respectively, for the reductive transformation of carboxylic esters and acids to the corresponding alkanols. Particularly, the cobalt-catalyzed hydrogenation of carbonates into their corresponding methanol and diols/alkanols was demonstrated experimentally viable by the groups of Beller and Sundararaju [16]. Meanwhile, Beller presented one case of general and efficient cobalt-catalyzed hydrodeoxygenation of amides to amines under mild conditions, wherein a combination of [Co(NTf2)2] and (p-anisyl)triphos was employed as the catalyst in the presence of [Me3SiOTf] as acidic co-catalyst [17]. On the other hand, a survey of literatures on the cobalt-catalyzed reduction of carboxylic substrates suggested that the use of silanes as reductants has great potential and is worthy of attention [14,18]. The reactivity of such reagents and related intermediates could be modulated by the substituents on the silicon atoms, thereby enabling a highly chemo- and regio-selective reduction protocol. For instance, the pincer cobalt-catalyzed chemo-selective reduction of esters could be reached by adjusting the stoichiometry of diethylsilane, leading to aldehydes and alcohols, respectively [14]. In this domain, the precedent work of Leitner’s group reported Co(NMePNP)Cl2-catalyzed adaptive and selective hydrogenation of CO2 with silanes individually to either the formic acid, the formaldehyde, or the methanol level [19]. Very recently, our study demonstrated that the level of Co(dppbsa)-catalyzed reduction of nitroaromatics and CO2, respectively, could be modulated by a specific structure and composition of silanes [20]. It thereby enables the chemoselective N,N-dimethylation of nitroaromatics with CO2 using a combination of PhSiH3 and Et3SiH as the reductant. Inspired by these results and the contemporaneous investigations on the reactivity of phosphinesulfonate transitional metal complexes in our group, we envisioned the combination of Co(dppbsa) as the catalyst and silanes as the reductant may enable the hydrodeoxygenation of carboxylic substrates. To our delight, Co(dppbsa)-catalyzed exhaustive reduction of aromatic esters and carboxylic acids was approached with NaBArF 4 as the basic additive and (MeO)2MeSiH as the reductant (Scheme 1B). Particularly, this Co-catalyzed exhaustive reduction proceeds through ether intermediates, which is distinct from both Ni- and Ti-catalysis [8,9]. Experimental combined theoretical results demonstrated the catalysis follows an outer-sphere ionic hydrosilylation mechanism and the in situ formed cationic siloxane species are involved in the rate-limiting hydride transfer. 2 Results and discussion The Co(dppbsa)-catalyzed hydrodeoxygenation of esters was examined using methyl benzoate (1a) as the feedstock and silane as the reductant (Table 1 and Table S1). To our delight, the exhaustive reduction product (2a) was obtained with an excellent yield of 93% when the reduction of 1a (0.2 mmol) with (MeO)2MeSiH (10 equiv.) was conducted in the presence of Co(dppbsa) (5 mol%) and NaBArF 4 (15 mol%) at 150 °C in cyclohexane for 8 h under argon (entry 1). It’s accompanied with the formation of (methoxymethyl)benzene (3a) and benzylalcohol (4a) as the side products. Despite persisting the same chemoselectivity, neither Co(dppbsa) nor NaBArF 4 alone could deliver such a high activity (entries 2 and 3). Further, the reduction of 1a did not occur at all without Co(dppbsa) and NaBArF 4 (entry 4). Both the conversion of 1a and the selectivity toward 2a decreased by shortening the reaction time and it mainly provided 3a instead (entry 5 vs. entry 6). On the other hand, the reaction was partially terminated at 3a by reducing the dosage of NaBArF 4 (entry 7). Meanwhile, it significantly loosed the activity when the reaction temperature was decreased from 150 °C to 120 °C (entry 7 vs. entry 8). During the condition optimization, the silane type was found to strongly influence the reactivity and product distribution (entries 9∼13 vs. entry 8). A high conversion was received with PhSiH3, but changing the selectivity to a mixture of 3a and 4a. The activity of both TMDSO and Et3SiH was comparatively weakened, leading to 3a as the major product. By contrast, (EtO)2MeSiH, as an analogue to (MeO)2MeSiH, provides a comparable reactivity and product distribution (entry 12 vs. entry 8). However, it resulted in a mixture of 2a and 3a in almost equal distribution by using (EtO)3SiH (entry 13). We next examined the limit and scope of esters (1) under the sandard conditions (Scheme 2 A). It was observed that electronic donating substituents at the para-position of methyl benzoate only slightly affected the reaction efficiency. The corresponding exhaustive reduction products substituted with a dimethylamino (2b), methoxyl (2c), methyl (2d), and phenol (2e) group were obtained in higher yields as compared with the pristine 2a. However, the situation for methyl benzoate bearing electron-withdrawing groups (1f∼1j) is complicated. For instance, a half conversion was detected for para-chloride derivative (1f) along with a high selectivity to 2f and no dechlorination product was detected. By contrast, the bromide analogue (1g) provided a satisfied yield of 2g and the debromination product with 18% yield. A similar result was observed for the naphthalene derivatives (1h vs. 1i). On the other hand, it provided slightly lower efficiency compared to the benzyl pristine (1a and 1h) probably due to their different conjugated effect on the ester functionality. In comparison, the para-phenyl derivative (1j) delivered a comparable result as 1a. To our surprise, the para-trifluoromethyl derivative (1k) did not respond at all (Scheme 2C). Meanwhile, the steric effect was slightly observed when introducing substituents to the meta- and ortho-position as the performance of methyl-derivative (1l and 1m vs. 1d) decreased in an order of 2d (93%) > 2l (90%) > 2m (88%). Heteroaromatic esters, such as 1n, were applied but performed poorly due to poisoning the active centre by strong chelation effect (Scheme 2C). In particular, the pyridine moiety in 1o was fully reduced along the exhaustive reduction of ester functionality, yielding 6-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline in 42% GC yield. Similarly, the nitro group could not survive under such conditions, which was preferentially reduced to primary amine and thereby terminated the reaction by poisoning the catalyst. For instance, the reaction of 1p provided methyl 4-aminobenzoate and 4-toluidine with 70% and 15% yield (Scheme 2C), respectively. However, preferential reduction of the aromatic ester over the conjugated olefin was detected for 1q, mainly leading to (E)-1-methyl-4-styrylbenzene. The tolerance of alkoxyl functionality at aromatic esters was next examined. Evidently, the reaction activity was significantly reduced by changing methoxy (1a) to phenylethoxy (1r) group. Meanwhile, (2-methoxyethyl)benzene was obtained in a comparable yield to 2a. Besides, the cyclic benzyl esters of 1s and 1t provided a considerable amount of ether products (3s: 58%, 3t: 79%) (Scheme 2C). In addition, the exhaustive reduction did not occur for aliphatic esters (1u and 1v), which mainly terminated at the corresponding ethers (3u and 3v) (Scheme 2C). These results suggest that the cleavage of ether C−O bonds under the Co-catalysis is affected by both electronic and steric hindrance effects. With success in the exhaustive reduction of aromatic esters, we turned our attention to the challenging feedstock of carboxylic acids (5, Scheme 2B). It proceeded smoothly for aromatic carboxylic acids (5a∼5n), resulting in a good-to-excellent yield of the corresponding tolyl derivatives. To our surprise, the heteroatomic functional group (e.g., 5e) was well tolerated in this case. Besides, the dehalogenation was not detected in the reduction of not only 5j but also 5k. Such a preferential reactivity could be attributed to the strong coordination of carboxylate ligand. However, the ortho-isomer of 5j exhibited a significant position effect, which mainly delivered the dechlorination product of 2a (Scheme S1). Besides, the aliphatic acid of 5o was not applicable in terms of exhaustive reduction (Scheme 2C), which terminated at the corresponding alkanol with 35% GC yield. The tolerance of amide feedstocks with the newly developed protocol was also examined by taking 6a as the benchmark substrate (Table S2). However, only the secondary amine 7a was detected in 58 % GC yield under the standard conditions (Table S2, entry 1). Reaction conditions varying the solvents, temperatures, catalyst dosages, and silanes were studied. The best yield of 7a (92%) was then obtained from the reaction of 6a with TMDSO (5.0 equiv.) at 120 °C for 24 h in the presence of Co(dppbsa) (5 mol%) and NaBArF 4 (5 mol%) in toluene under argon. Next, the reactivity of different amides under the improved reaction conditions was further explored (Scheme 3 ). In general, good to excellent yields were obtained for both N-aryl benzamides (6a and 6b) and acetamides (6f∼6m) except for para-amino-N-phenylbenzamide (6e). In addition to the N-aryl benzamides, two N-alkyl benzamides (6c and 6d) were hydrogenated in 92% and 97% yield, respectively. Interestingly, the para-trifluoromethyl derivative (6j) was better tolerated than the ester counterpart (1k, Scheme 2), potentially due to a higher nucleophilicity of amide versus ester. Besides, both N-phenyl propionamide (6n) and decanamide (6o) provides the secondary amines (7n and 7o) in high yields. It could also extent to the cyclic amides (6p∼6t), leading to cyclic amines with good-to-excellent yields. Interestingly, the aliphatic cyclic amide substrate such as ε-caprolactame (6t) afforded a satisfactory yield of the desired product (7t). To probe whether the Co(dppbsa)-NaBArF 4 system reacts homogeneously or heterogeneously, the standard hydrogenolysis of 1a (ester), 5a (carboxylic acid) and 6a (amide) in the presence of a 100-fold excess of mercury with respect to the catalyst of Co(dppbsa) were conducted (Tables S3−S4). It showed that both conversion and yield remained basically unchanged for all cases. In addition, significant dechlorination was observed for ortho-chlorobenzoic acid rather than the para-isomer (Scheme 2B and Scheme S1), suggesting the presence of directing effect by an acid group during the catalysis [21]. Finally, products from hydrogenation of the arene ring were nearly not detected in any of the experiments on the exhaustive reduction of aromatic esters (1) and acids (5) (Scheme 2), contrasting with that for hydrogenation over heterogeneous catalysts [6d]. These results demonstrated that the Co(dppbsa)-NaBArF 4 catalysis follows a homogeneous process. To approach the unusual exhaustive reduction of aromatic esters (1) and carboxylic acids (5), the feedstock might be instantaneously transformed to benzyl ethers (3), alkanols (4), or aldehydes (8). Our condition screening for the exhaustive reduction of 1a (entries 1, 5 and 6, Table 1) demonstrated the formation of 2a is accompanied by an increase followed by a decrease in 3a, strongly suggesting that the latter acts as one of the steady-state intermediates. To further understand the details and the catalytic pathway for both aromatic esters and carboxylic acids, the catalytic reduction of related oxygen-based substrates (O-Sub, 1a, 5a, 3a, 4a, and 8a) was examined and the time-course plots within the first hour were recorded for comparison (Fig. 1 ). Firstly, a quantitative formation of 2a was reached (Fig. 1A) under the standard conditions except for 5a, which performed relatively poor. Besides, the time-course plots clearly demonstrated that the presence of 3a during the exhaustive reduction of 1a, 5a, 4a, and 8a, but with different rates of formation and consumption (Fig. S1). By contrast, the production of 4a (from 1a, 5a, 3a, 8a) and 8a (from 1a, 5a, 3a, 4a) can be nearly neglected from the time-course plots of respective reaction. We further noticed that the initial formation rate leading to 2a follows a decreasing order of 4a (5.36 mM/min) > 3a (2.83 mM/min) > 8a (0.25 mM/min) within the first 0.5 h (Fig. 1B). Meanwhile, the contemporaneous formation of 3a from 8a proceeds remarkably faster than that of 2a (61.03 mM/min vs. 0.25 mM/min, Fig. 1B and C). In comparison, the hydrogenolysis of 1a (0.86 mM/min vs. 0.23 mM/min) and 5a (2.02 mM/min vs. 0.23 mM/min) are analogous to that of 8a, wherein the initial rate to 3a is faster than that to 2a and the latter by these three substrates are comparable (Fig. 1B and C). Therefore, we supposed the exhaustive reduction of aromatic esters and carboxylic acids follows either an acid/ester-aldehyde-ether-alkane conversion or an acid/ester-ether-alkane conversion route. By contrast, different results were observed for 4a, which delivered a slightly faster initial rate to 2a (5.36 mM/min, Fig. 1B) versus 3a (3.61 mM/min, Fig. 1C). These results suggested that the alkanol-to-alkane conversion prefers a direct deoxygenation route, while the route via an ether intermediate cannot be completely ruled out from the process. To trap the potential intermediates of aldehyde, a set of cross experiments were conducted (Table 2 ). The exhaustive reduction of 8a under standard conditions was significantly inhibited in the presence of pyrrolidine (entry 1), which instead quantitatively provided the reductive amination product of 7u. In contrast, the analogous reaction of 1a proceeded sluggishly, providing a trace of 7u and amide 6u (entry 2). Meanwhile, the independent reaction of 1a without (MeO)2MeSiH (entry 3) moderately generated 6u. It signified that the ester-to-ether conversion was completely inhibited by poisoning silane related species with pyrrolidine. Interestingly, the same trapping experiment on 5a delivered 7u and 6u with yields of 25% and 50% (entry 4), respectively. However, 6u was obtained in a low yield of 17% when the reaction was carried out without (MeO)2MeSiH (entry 5). Apparently, the fast formation of ether from carboxylic acids counts for the formation of 6u and 7u and the silane reagent should be involved in the nucleophilic substitution of 5a by pyrrolidine (leading to 6u). However, the major product of 6u rather than 7u from 5a (entry 4), as compared to the reactivity of 8a (entry 1), excludes the transient stage of aldehydes. Cross experiments further confirmed the condensation of aldehydes with amines readily occurred under the standard conditions, while the catalytic hydrogenation of the corresponding imines proceeded with much poor activity (Scheme S2). Thus, the deoxygenation of amides should be too fast to release aldehydes, which once formed may significantly lead to imine side-products. Our results strongly suggest the silane not only functions as a reductant, but also participates in the catalytic cycle. Based on the literatures, it most likely follows an outer-sphere catalysis, wherein a highly electrophilic silyl cation intermediate was generated to enable the reaction with a wide range of nucleophiles by catalytic reduction [22]. In general, the reductive deoxygenation of carboxylic compounds (esters, carboxylic acids, and amides) to ethers and amines accounts for the first stage. Herein, the formation of benzyl ethers from carboxylic acids involves a step of transalkylation with the silane reagent of (MeO)2MeSiH (Scheme S3), which is also experienced by aldehyde, alkanol, and even ester substrates (Scheme S4) [23]. But it’s highly related to the substrate structure, as no corresponding ethers were detected for aliphatic acids (e.g. 5o, Scheme 2) and aliphatic alkanols (e.g. 4u, Scheme S4) under the same conditions. The reactivity of Co(dppbsa)-NaBArF 4 system makes it possible to cleave benzyl ether C−O bonds (rather than benzyl amine C−N bonds) with silanes, delivering the exhaustive reduction of aromatic esters and carboxylic acids. Representatively, the pathway of Co(dppbsa)-catalyzed reduction of benzyl ethers was proposed in Scheme 4 . First, the pre-catalyst of Co(dppbsa) is deiodinated by NaBArF 4 to give transient cationic complex I, which was observed by ESI-MS analysis of a mixture of Co(dppbsa) and NaBArF 4 (Fig. S2). The cobalt complex I activates the silane reagent through a sulfate-ligand assistant manner, which leads to ionic cobaltic hydride complex II. It has been approached by the cooperation between the non-coordinated oxygen atoms of an ancillary trifluoromethanesulfonato ligand and the iridium(III) metal center [24]. Subsequently, a silyl cation was released to react with nucleophilic benzyl ether (3), delivering ether adduct 3′ and neutral cobaltic hydride complex III. Finally, hydride reduction of 3′ with complex III gives the exhaustive reduction product of 2 and recycle the cobalt complex I (cycle A). However, the presence of a cobaltic dihydride species such as complex IV may be necessary for the hydride reduction of 3′ (cycle B), which was supposed formed by activation of Si−H bond on the second molecular silane with complex III. Alternatively, the hydride reduction of 3′ may proceeds with silane as the hydride donor (cycle C), which generates products and returns the silyl cation (V). To our delight, the formation of complex I was recognized by UV–vis analysis, wherein the typical feature of Co(dppbsa) at 598 nm has shifted to 526 nm by the addition of NaBArF 4 (Fig. S3). However, efforts on identify the consequent cobaltic hydride complexes were failed due to the poor solubility under catalytic conditions (Fig. S4). Furthermore, to verify whether the stability of V is sufficient to turnover the reaction, the Corey reaction by reacting triphenylmethylium tetrakis-(pentafluorophenyl)borate, [Ph3C][B(C6F5)4], with neat (MeO)2MeSiH in the presence of CD3CN as nucleophile was conducted [25]. The peak of 29Si NMR (Figs. S5 and S6) changed from −12.77 ppm (assigned to (MeO)2MeSiH) to 50.00 ppm, suggesting the formation of [(MeO)2MeSi(CD3CN)][B(C6F5)4] [25c]. To discern the reaction pathway for the cleavage of benzyl ether C−O bonds, density functional theory (DFT) calculation was conducted by taking 3a (BnOMe) as the substrate and (MeO)2MeSiH as the reductant (Fig. 2 ) [26]. A test on spin state showed that complex I adopts a singlet ground state, and the triplet state is 3.2 kcal/mol higher in free energy. Furthermore, the calculations were performed on the singlet state potential energy surface since most transient complexes involved possess strong-field hydride ligands. The formation of a bare silyl cation ([Si]+) from silane and complex I was found quite disfavored (48.3 kcal/mol). Instead, complex I is prone to undergoing a Si–H bond activation in a sulfate-ligand assistant manner, resulting in the formation of complex II. It’s followed by a rapid [Si]-transfer into 3a to afford complex III and BnO(Me)[Si]+ (3a′). This [Si]-transfer process exhibits no transition state, with the energy monotonously changes along the reaction coordinate. Once the active 3a′ is formed, it may face multiple reaction pathways. An uncatalyzed hydride transfer from silane to 3a′ requires a high overall barrier of 29.9 kcal/mol, through TS3′-V . The catalyzed pathway, instead, requires a low overall barrier of 18.2 kcal/mol, via an SN2-type TSIII-I , to release toluene as the product, and to recover the complex I. The alternative potential cylce B requires the second hydrosilylation of complex III, through TSIII-IV , to afford the cobaltic dihydride complex IV. However, the formation of complex IV is blocked by the high energy of TSIII-IV (39.6 kcal/mol). Therefore, monohydride III is suggested to be the active hydride donor, and the catalytic cycle A is preferred. Besides, the catalytic hydride transfer from complex III to the active 3a′ accounts for the rate-limiting step. Based on these fundamental discussions on the mechanism of Co(dppbsa)-catalyzed reductive deoxygenation of benzyl ethers as the nucleophilic substrate, a tentative pathway for the formation of benzyl ethers from various O-Sub (1, 5, 4, and 8) was proposed (Scheme S3). The selectivity for Co(dppbsa)-catalyzed exhaustive reduction of aromatic esters and carboxylic acids over the aliphatic counterpart contrasts with that by B(C6F5)3−Et3SiH system (Scheme 1B) [7]. Besides, compared to the other two available protocols (Scheme 1B), the reaction pathway for Co-catalysis leading to exhaustive reduction is apparently different. In Newman’s study, Ni-catalyzed exhaustive reduction of aromatic esters was achieved by an organosilane-mediated rapid ester-to-alkanol transformation and subsequent Ni/NHC-catalyzed hydrogenolysis [8]. It leaves aromatic ethers untouched due to the choice of ligand and the presence of basic KO t Bu. Importantly, a more aggressive hypervalent O t Bu siloxane reducing agent was supposed to form in situ as a key feature to turn over the catalysis. In comparison, the Ti-catalysis by Wu’s group proceeded with the inter-stage of aldehydes, wherein the in situ generated Ti(III)-H species was vital for such a transformation [9]. Herein, the Co(dppbsa)-NaBArF 4 catalytic system runs through ethers intermediates. It exhibited slightly different functional groups and spatial structure tolerance in terms of exhaustive reduction of esters compared to Ni/NHC-catalysis, while persisting better activity toward aromatic acids than Ti-catalysis. Mechanistic studies and precedent literature both support the cationic siloxane species being involved in the rate-limiting hydride transfer. It’s highly consistent with the experimental findings (Table 1) that the reaction efficiency is closely related to the silane structure. Kinetically, a proper electronic and steric structure of the ionic silyl adduct 3a′ is necessary for the reductive deoxygenation, especially in the case of using a bulky III as the hydride donor. Besides, it’s crucial to enable the reaction by delivering the intermediates of III (through Si−H bond activation) and 3a′ (with high electrophilicity and less steric hindrance of silyl cation). Related hydrosilation chemistry for the exhaustive reduction of alkyl ethers has been reported by the cationic iridium pincer complex catalysis with Et3SiH [22]. Both the neutral Ir hydride complex and Et3SiH could function as the hydride donor depending on the reactivity of C−O bonds in the ether substrates. Particularly, the reduction of in situ formed cationic siloxane by Et2O ([Et3SiOEt2]+[B(C6F5)4]−) involves neutral dihydride Ir complex, while Et3SiH was found to attack that of less basic and more hindered EtOSiEt3. In this study, using benzyl alkanol (4a) as a starting material in the presence of Co(dppbsa) resulted in faster formation of alkane 2a than ether 3a at the initial stage (Fig. 1B and C). The relative rates for cleavage of benzyl alkyl ethers and benzyl alkanols were estimated by conducting competition experiments in which two substrates (3a and 4d) are present in the same vessel (Scheme S5), confirming the latter has a faster rate of hydrogenolysis. In addition, for benzyl 4-methylbenzoate (1w) substrate, comparable yields of 2a and 2d were concurrently obtained under the standard conditions, without detecting any benzyl silyl ether or the transformed alkanols (Scheme S5). For clarity, it’s further demonstrated that the rate constant for cleavage of benzyl C−O bond in benzyl silyl ether (BnO[Si]), which was supposed rapidly formed by reacting alkanols with silanes, is larger than that for benzyl ethers upon simulating and comparing the time course of exhaustive reduction of 3a and 4a (Scheme S6, Fig. S7). Available data do not allow one to distinguish the hydride donor for benzyl silyl ethers under the Co(dppbsa)-NaBArF 4-catalyzed hydrogenolysis, but the less basic character will accelerate the rate-limiting hydride transfer. 3 Conclusions In summary, the exhaustive reduction of aromatic esters and carboxylic acids was approached by a well-defined phosphinesulfonate chelated cobalt catalyst (Co(dppbsa)). The in situ formed cationic Co(III) complex by reacting with basic NaBArF 4, combined with (MeO)2MeSiH as the reductant, were found indispensable to turnover the catalysis. Experimental combined theoretical results demonstrated the catalysis proceeds through ether intermediates and the cationic siloxane species being involved in the rate-limiting hydride transfer. The unusual reactivity is attributed to the sulfonate ligand-assisted Si–H activation of (MeO)2MeSiH, which enables the formation of cationic siloxane and neutral cobaltic hydride complex in a concerted approach. The same system also enables the catalytic deoxygenation of aliphatic esters, aliphatic acids, and amides but terminating at the corresponding ethers, alkanols and secondary amines. This study provides a powerful protocol for the deoxygenation of carboxylic skeletons. Further studies on the exhaustive reduction of esters or polyesters catalyzed by cobalt complexes are currently underway in our lab. coredata.dc:description: A one-step procedure to exhaustively reduce aromatic esters and carboxylic acids to their corresponding tolyl derivatives is a significant transformation in organic synthesis, which remains challenging in homogeneous catalysis. In this study, it’s achieved by using the well-defined phosphinesulfonate chelated cobalt-based catalyst (Co(dppbsa)), along with NaBArF 4 as the basic additive and (MeO)2MeSiH as the reductant. Particularly, this cobalt catalysis proceeds through ether intermediates. Experimental combined theoretical results support it follows an outer-sphere ionic hydrosilylation mechanism and the in situ formed cationic siloxane species are involved in the rate-limiting hydride transfer. The same system also enables the catalytic deoxygenation of aliphatic esters, aliphatic acids, and amides but terminating at the corresponding ethers, alkanols and secondary amines, respectively. These findings open up novel avenues for the catalytic application of phosphinesulfonate chelated complexes, potentially serving as the foundation for the exhaustive reduction of carboxylic skeletons with cobalt.
